segments.en: Middle Discourses 50
The Rebuke of Māra
So I have heard.

segments.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ āyasmā mahāmoggallāno bhaggesu viharati susumāragire bhesakaḷāvane migadāye.
segments.en: At one time Venerable Mahāmoggallāna was staying in the land of the Bhaggas on Crocodile Hill, in the deer park at Bhesakaḷā’s Wood.

segments.pli: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmā mahāmoggallāno abbhokāse caṅkamati.
segments.en: At that time Moggallāna was walking meditation in the open air.

segments.pli: Tena kho pana samayena māro pāpimā āyasmato mahāmoggallānassa kucchigato hoti koṭṭhamanupaviṭṭho.
segments.en: Now at that time Māra the Wicked had got inside Moggallāna’s belly.
Moggallāna thought,

segments.pli: “kiṃ nu kho me kucchi garugaro viya?
segments.en: “Why now is my belly so very heavy,
like I’ve just eaten a load of beans?”

segments.pli: Atha kho āyasmā mahāmoggallāno caṅkamā orohitvā vihāraṃ pavisitvā paññatte āsane nisīdi.
segments.en: Then he stepped down from the walking path, entered his dwelling, sat down on the seat spread out,

segments.pli: Nisajja kho āyasmā mahāmoggallāno paccattaṃ yoniso manasākāsi.
segments.en: and investigated inside himself.

segments.pli: Addasā kho āyasmā mahāmoggallāno māraṃ pāpimantaṃ kucchigataṃ koṭṭhamanupaviṭṭhaṃ.
segments.en: He saw that Māra the Wicked had got inside his belly.
So he said to Māra,
“Come out, Wicked One,
come out!
Do not harass the Realized One or his disciple.

segments.pli: Mā te ahosi dīgharattaṃ ahitāya dukkhāyā”ti.
segments.en: Don’t create lasting harm and suffering for yourself!”
Then Māra thought,

segments.pli: “ajānameva kho maṃ ayaṃ samaṇo apassaṃ evamāha:
segments.en: “This ascetic doesn’t really know me or see me when he tells me to come out.

segments.pli: Mā te ahosi dīgharattaṃ ahitāya dukkhāyā’ti.
Yopissa so satthā sopi maṃ neva khippaṃ jāneyya, kuto pana maṃ ayaṃ sāvako jānissatī”ti?
segments.en: Not even the Teacher could recognize me so quickly, so how could a disciple?”

segments.pli: Atha kho āyasmā mahāmoggallāno māraṃ pāpimantaṃ etadavoca:
segments.en: Then Moggallāna said to Māra,

segments.pli: “evampi kho tāhaṃ, pāpima, jānāmi, mā tvaṃ maññittho:
segments.en: “I know you even when you’re like this, Wicked One. Do not think,
‘He doesn’t know me.’
You are Māra the Wicked.
And you think,

segments.pli: ‘ajānameva kho maṃ ayaṃ samaṇo apassaṃ evamāha—
segments.en: ‘This ascetic doesn’t really know me or see me when he tells me to come out.

segments.pli: Mā te ahosi dīgharattaṃ ahitāya dukkhāyāti.
Yopissa so satthā sopi maṃ neva khippaṃ jāneyya, kuto pana maṃ ayaṃ sāvako jānissatī’”ti?
segments.en: Not even the Teacher could recognize me so quickly, so how could a disciple?’”
Then Māra thought,

segments.pli: “jānameva kho maṃ ayaṃ samaṇo passaṃ evamāha:
segments.en: “This ascetic really does know me and see me when he tells me to come out.”

segments.pli: Mā te ahosi dīgharattaṃ ahitāya dukkhāyā’”ti.
Atha kho māro pāpimā āyasmato mahāmoggallānassa mukhato uggantvā paccaggaḷe aṭṭhāsi.
segments.en: Then Māra came up out of Moggallāna’s mouth and stood against the door bar.

segments.pli: Addasā kho āyasmā mahāmoggallāno māraṃ pāpimantaṃ paccaggaḷe ṭhitaṃ;
segments.en: Moggallāna saw him there
and said,

segments.pli: “etthāpi kho tāhaṃ, pāpima, passāmi; mā tvaṃ maññittho
segments.en: “I see you even there, Wicked One. Do not think,
‘He doesn’t see me.’
That’s you, Wicked One, standing against the door bar.

segments.pli: Bhūtapubbāhaṃ, pāpima, dūsī nāma māro ahosiṃ, tassa me kāḷī nāma bhaginī.
segments.en: Once upon a time, Wicked One, I was a Māra named Dūsī, and I had a sister named Kāḷī.
You were her son,
which made you my nephew.

segments.pli: Tena kho pana, pāpima, samayena kakusandho bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho loke uppanno hoti.
segments.en: At that time Kakusandha, the Blessed One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha arose in the world.

segments.pli: Kakusandhassa kho pana, pāpima, bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa vidhurasañjīvaṃ nāma sāvakayugaṃ ahosi aggaṃ bhaddayugaṃ.
segments.en: Kakusandha had a fine pair of chief disciples named Vidhura and Sañjīva.

segments.pli: Yāvatā kho pana, pāpima, kakusandhassa bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa sāvakā.
segments.en: Of all the disciples of the Buddha Kakusandha,

segments.pli: Tesu na ca koci āyasmatā vidhurena samasamo hoti yadidaṃ dhammadesanāya.
segments.en: none were the equal of Venerable Vidhura in teaching Dhamma.

segments.pli: Iminā kho evaṃ, pāpima, pariyāyena āyasmato vidhurassa vidhuroteva samaññā udapādi.
segments.en: And that’s how he came to be known as Vidhura.

segments.pli: Āyasmā pana, pāpima, sañjīvo araññagatopi rukkhamūlagatopi suññāgāragatopi appakasireneva saññāvedayitanirodhaṃ samāpajjati.
segments.en: But when Venerable Sañjīva had gone to a wilderness, or to the root of a tree, or to an empty hut, he easily attained the cessation of perception and feeling.

segments.pli: Bhūtapubbaṃ, pāpima, āyasmā sañjīvo aññatarasmiṃ rukkhamūle saññāvedayitanirodhaṃ samāpanno nisinno hoti.
segments.en: Once upon a time, Sañjīva was sitting at the root of a certain tree having attained the cessation of perception and feeling.

segments.pli: Addasaṃsu kho, pāpima, gopālakā pasupālakā kassakā pathāvino āyasmantaṃ sañjīvaṃ aññatarasmiṃ rukkhamūle saññāvedayitanirodhaṃ samāpannaṃ nisinnaṃ;
segments.en: Some cowherds, shepherds, farmers, and passers-by saw him sitting there
and said,
‘It’s incredible, it’s amazing!
This ascetic passed away while sitting.
We should cremate him.’

segments.pli: Atha kho te, pāpima, gopālakā pasupālakā kassakā pathāvino tiṇañca kaṭṭhañca gomayañca saṅkaḍḍhitvā āyasmato sañjīvassa kāye upacinitvā aggiṃ datvā pakkamiṃsu.
segments.en: They collected grass, wood, and cow-dung, heaped it all on Sañjīva’s body, set it on fire, and left.

segments.pli: Atha kho, pāpima, āyasmā sañjīvo tassā rattiyā accayena tāya samāpattiyā vuṭṭhahitvā cīvarāni papphoṭetvā pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya gāmaṃ piṇḍāya pāvisi.
segments.en: Then, when the night had passed, Sañjīva emerged from that attainment, shook out his robes, and, since it was morning, he robed up and entered the village for alms.

segments.pli: Addasaṃsu kho te, pāpima, gopālakā pasupālakā kassakā pathāvino āyasmantaṃ sañjīvaṃ piṇḍāya carantaṃ;
segments.en: Those cowherds, shepherds, farmers, and passers-by saw him wandering for alms
and said,
‘It’s incredible, it’s amazing!

segments.pli: Ayaṃ samaṇo nisinnakova kālaṅkato, svāyaṃ paṭisañjīvito’ti.
segments.en: This ascetic passed away while sitting, and now he has come back to life!’

segments.pli: Iminā kho evaṃ, pāpima, pariyāyena āyasmato sañjīvassa sañjīvoteva samaññā udapādi.
segments.en: And that’s how he came to be known as Sañjīva.

segments.pli: Atha kho, pāpima, dūsissa mārassa etadahosi:
segments.en: Then it occurred to Māra Dūsī,

segments.pli: ‘imesaṃ kho ahaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ sīlavantānaṃ kalyāṇadhammānaṃ neva jānāmi āgatiṃ vā gatiṃ vā.
segments.en: ‘I don’t know the course of rebirth of these ethical mendicants of good character.
Why don’t I take possession of these brahmins and householders and say,

segments.pli: etha, tumhe bhikkhū sīlavante kalyāṇadhamme akkosatha paribhāsatha rosetha vihesetha.
segments.en: “Come, all of you, abuse, attack, harass, and trouble the ethical mendicants of good character.

segments.pli: Appeva nāma tumhehi akkosiyamānānaṃ paribhāsiyamānānaṃ rosiyamānānaṃ vihesiyamānānaṃ siyā cittassa aññathattaṃ, yathā taṃ dūsī māro labhetha otāran’ti.
segments.en: Hopefully by doing this we can upset their minds so that Māra Dūsī can find a vulnerability.”’

segments.pli: Atha kho te, pāpima, dūsī māro brāhmaṇagahapatike anvāvisi:
segments.en: And that’s exactly what he did.

segments.pli: ‘etha, tumhe bhikkhū sīlavante kalyāṇadhamme akkosatha paribhāsatha rosetha vihesetha.
Appeva nāma tumhehi akkosiyamānānaṃ paribhāsiyamānānaṃ rosiyamānānaṃ vihesiyamānānaṃ siyā cittassa aññathattaṃ, yathā taṃ dūsī māro labhetha otāran’ti.
Atha kho te, pāpima, brāhmaṇagahapatikā anvāvisiṭṭhā dūsinā mārena bhikkhū sīlavante kalyāṇadhamme akkosanti paribhāsanti rosenti vihesenti:
segments.en: Then those brahmins and householders abused, attacked, harassed, and troubled the ethical mendicants of good character:

segments.pli: ‘ime pana muṇḍakā samaṇakā ibbhā kiṇhā bandhupādāpaccā “jhāyinosmā jhāyinosmā”ti pattakkhandhā adhomukhā madhurakajātā jhāyanti pajjhāyanti nijjhāyanti apajjhāyanti.
segments.en: ‘These shavelings, fake ascetics, riffraff, black spawn from the feet of our Kinsman, say, ‘We practice absorption meditation! We practice absorption meditation!’ And they meditate and concentrate and contemplate and ruminate.

segments.pli: Seyyathāpi nāma ulūko rukkhasākhāyaṃ mūsikaṃ maggayamāno jhāyati pajjhāyati nijjhāyati apajjhāyati;
segments.en: They’re just like an owl on a branch, which meditates and concentrates and contemplates and ruminates as it hunts a mouse.

segments.pli: evamevime muṇḍakā samaṇakā ibbhā kiṇhā bandhupādāpaccā “jhāyinosmā jhāyinosmā”ti pattakkhandhā adhomukhā madhurakajātā jhāyanti pajjhāyanti nijjhāyanti apajjhāyanti.
Seyyathāpi nāma kotthu nadītīre macche maggayamāno jhāyati pajjhāyati nijjhāyati apajjhāyati;
segments.en: They’re just like a jackal on a river-bank, which meditates and concentrates and contemplates and ruminates as it hunts a fish.

segments.pli: evamevime muṇḍakā samaṇakā ibbhā kiṇhā bandhupādāpaccā “jhāyinosmā jhāyinosmā”ti pattakkhandhā adhomukhā madhurakajātā jhāyanti pajjhāyanti nijjhāyanti apajjhāyanti.
Seyyathāpi nāma biḷāro sandhisamalasaṅkaṭīre mūsikaṃ maggayamāno jhāyati pajjhāyati nijjhāyati apajjhāyati;
segments.en: They’re just like a cat by an alley or a drain or a dustbin, which meditates and concentrates and contemplates and ruminates as it hunts a mouse.

segments.pli: evamevime muṇḍakā samaṇakā ibbhā kiṇhā bandhupādāpaccā “jhāyinosmā jhāyinosmā”ti pattakkhandhā adhomukhā madhurakajātā jhāyanti pajjhāyanti nijjhāyanti apajjhāyanti.
Seyyathāpi nāma gadrabho vahacchinno sandhisamalasaṅkaṭīre jhāyati pajjhāyati nijjhāyati apajjhāyati;
segments.en: They’re just like an unladen donkey by an alley or a drain or a dustbin, which meditates and concentrates and contemplates and ruminates.

segments.pli: evamevime muṇḍakā samaṇakā ibbhā kiṇhā bandhupādāpaccā “jhāyinosmā jhāyinosmā”ti pattakkhandhā adhomukhā madhurakajātā jhāyanti pajjhāyanti nijjhāyanti apajjhāyantī’ti.
segments.en: In the same way, these shavelings, fake ascetics, riffraff, black spawn from the feet of our Kinsman, say, ‘We practice absorption meditation! We practice absorption meditation!’ And they meditate and concentrate and contemplate and ruminate.’

segments.pli: Ye kho pana, pāpima, tena samayena manussā kālaṃ karonti yebhuyyena kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapajjanti.
segments.en: Most of the people who died at that time—when their body broke up, after death—were reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.

segments.pli: Atha kho, pāpima, kakusandho bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho bhikkhū āmantesi:
segments.en: Then Kakusandha the Blessed One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha, addressed the mendicants:
‘Mendicants, the brahmins and householders have been possessed by Māra Dūsī.

segments.pli: etha, tumhe bhikkhū sīlavante kalyāṇadhamme akkosatha paribhāsatha rosetha vihesetha, appeva nāma tumhehi akkosiyamānānaṃ paribhāsiyamānānaṃ rosiyamānānaṃ vihesiyamānānaṃ siyā cittassa aññathattaṃ, yathā taṃ dūsī māro labhetha otāran’ti.
segments.en: He told them to abuse you in the hope of upsetting your minds so that he can find a vulnerability.

segments.pli: Etha, tumhe, bhikkhave, mettāsahagatena cetasā ekaṃ disaṃ pharitvā viharatha, tathā dutiyaṃ, tathā tatiyaṃ, tathā catutthaṃ. Iti uddhamadho tiriyaṃ sabbadhi sabbattatāya sabbāvantaṃ lokaṃ mettāsahagatena cetasā vipulena mahaggatena appamāṇena averena abyābajjhena pharitvā viharatha.
segments.en: Come, all of you mendicants, meditate spreading a heart full of love to one direction, and to the second, and to the third, and to the fourth. In the same way above, below, across, everywhere, all around, spread a heart full of love to the whole world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.
Meditate spreading a heart full of compassion …
Meditate spreading a heart full of rejoicing …

segments.pli: upekkhāsahagatena cetasā ekaṃ disaṃ pharitvā viharatha, tathā dutiyaṃ, tathā tatiyaṃ, tathā catutthaṃ. Iti uddhamadho tiriyaṃ sabbadhi sabbattatāya sabbāvantaṃ lokaṃ upekkhāsahagatena cetasā vipulena mahaggatena appamāṇena averena abyābajjhena pharitvā viharathā’ti.
segments.en: Meditate spreading a heart full of equanimity to one direction, and to the second, and to the third, and to the fourth. In the same way above, below, across, everywhere, all around, spread a heart full of equanimity to the whole world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.’

segments.pli: Atha kho te, pāpima, bhikkhū kakusandhena bhagavatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena evaṃ ovadiyamānā evaṃ anusāsiyamānā araññagatāpi rukkhamūlagatāpi suññāgāragatāpi mettāsahagatena cetasā ekaṃ disaṃ pharitvā vihariṃsu, tathā dutiyaṃ, tathā tatiyaṃ, tathā catutthaṃ. Iti uddhamadho tiriyaṃ sabbadhi sabbattatāya sabbāvantaṃ lokaṃ mettāsahagatena cetasā vipulena mahaggatena appamāṇena averena abyābajjhena pharitvā vihariṃsu.
segments.en: When those mendicants were instructed and advised by the Buddha Kakusandha in this way, they went to a wilderness, or to the root of a tree, or to an empty hut, where they meditated spreading a heart full of love …
compassion …
rejoicing …

segments.pli: upekkhāsahagatena cetasā ekaṃ disaṃ pharitvā vihariṃsu, tathā dutiyaṃ, tathā tatiyaṃ, tathā catutthaṃ. Iti uddhamadho tiriyaṃ sabbadhi sabbattatāya sabbāvantaṃ lokaṃ upekkhāsahagatena cetasā vipulena mahaggatena appamāṇena averena abyābajjhena pharitvā vihariṃsu.
segments.en: equanimity.

segments.pli: Atha kho, pāpima, dūsissa mārassa etadahosi:
segments.en: Then it occurred to Māra Dūsī,

segments.pli: ‘evampi kho ahaṃ karonto imesaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ sīlavantānaṃ kalyāṇadhammānaṃ neva jānāmi āgatiṃ vā gatiṃ vā, yannūnāhaṃ brāhmaṇagahapatike anvāviseyyaṃ:
segments.en: ‘Even when I do this I don’t know the course of rebirth of these ethical mendicants of good character. Why don’t I take possession of these brahmins and householders and say,

segments.pli: “etha, tumhe bhikkhū sīlavante kalyāṇadhamme sakkarotha garuṃ karotha mānetha pūjetha,
segments.en: “Come, all of you, honor, respect, esteem, and venerate the ethical mendicants of good character.

segments.pli: appeva nāma tumhehi sakkariyamānānaṃ garukariyamānānaṃ māniyamānānaṃ pūjiyamānānaṃ siyā cittassa aññathattaṃ, yathā taṃ dūsī māro labhetha otāran”’ti.
segments.en: Hopefully by doing this we can upset their minds so that Māra Dūsī can find a vulnerability.”’

segments.pli: Atha kho te, pāpima, dūsī māro brāhmaṇagahapatike anvāvisi:
segments.en: And that’s exactly what he did.

segments.pli: ‘etha, tumhe bhikkhū sīlavante kalyāṇadhamme sakkarotha garuṃ karotha mānetha pūjetha,
appeva nāma tumhehi sakkariyamānānaṃ garukariyamānānaṃ māniyamānānaṃ pūjiyamānānaṃ siyā cittassa aññathattaṃ, yathā taṃ dūsī māro labhetha otāran’ti.
Atha kho te, pāpima, brāhmaṇagahapatikā anvāviṭṭhā dūsinā mārena bhikkhū sīlavante kalyāṇadhamme sakkaronti garuṃ karonti mānenti pūjenti.
segments.en: Then those brahmins and householders honored, respected, esteemed, and venerated the ethical mendicants of good character.

segments.pli: Ye kho pana, pāpima, tena samayena manussā kālaṃ karonti yebhuyyena kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjanti.
segments.en: Most of the people who died at that time—when their body broke up, after death—were reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.

segments.pli: Atha kho, pāpima, kakusandho bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho bhikkhū āmantesi:
segments.en: Then Kakusandha the Blessed One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha, addressed the mendicants:
‘Mendicants, the brahmins and householders have been possessed by Māra Dūsī.

segments.pli: “etha, tumhe bhikkhū sīlavante kalyāṇadhamme sakkarotha garuṃ karotha mānetha pūjetha,
segments.en: He told them to venerate you

segments.pli: appeva nāma tumhehi sakkariyamānānaṃ garukariyamānānaṃ māniyamānānaṃ pūjiyamānānaṃ siyā cittassa aññathattaṃ, yathā taṃ dūsī māro labhetha otāran”ti.
segments.en: in the hope of upsetting your minds so that he can find a vulnerability.

segments.pli: Etha, tumhe, bhikkhave, asubhānupassino kāye viharatha, āhāre paṭikūlasaññino, sabbaloke anabhiratisaññino, sabbasaṅkhāresu aniccānupassino’ti.
segments.en: Come, all you mendicants, meditate observing the ugliness of the body, perceiving the repulsiveness of food, perceiving dissatisfaction with the whole world, and observing the impermanence of all conditions.’

segments.pli: Atha kho te, pāpima, bhikkhū kakusandhena bhagavatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena evaṃ ovadiyamānā evaṃ anusāsiyamānā araññagatāpi rukkhamūlagatāpi suññāgāragatāpi asubhānupassino kāye vihariṃsu, āhāre paṭikūlasaññino, sabbaloke anabhiratisaññino, sabbasaṅkhāresu aniccānupassino.
segments.en: When those mendicants were instructed and advised by the Buddha Kakusandha in this way, they went to a wilderness, or to the root of a tree, or to an empty hut, where they meditated observing the ugliness of the body, perceiving the repulsiveness of food, perceiving dissatisfaction with the whole world, and observing the impermanence of all conditions.

segments.pli: Atha kho, pāpima, kakusandho bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya āyasmatā vidhurena pacchāsamaṇena gāmaṃ piṇḍāya pāvisi.
segments.en: Then the Buddha Kakusandha robed up in the morning and, taking this bowl and robe, entered the village for alms with Venerable Vidhura as his second monk.

segments.pli: Atha kho, pāpima, dūsī māro aññataraṃ kumārakaṃ anvāvisitvā sakkharaṃ gahetvā āyasmato vidhurassa sīse pahāramadāsi; sīsaṃ vobhindi.
segments.en: Then Māra Dūsī took possession of a certain boy, picked up a rock, and hit Vidhura on the head, cracking it open.

segments.pli: Atha kho, pāpima, āyasmā vidhuro bhinnena sīsena lohitena gaḷantena kakusandhaṃyeva bhagavantaṃ arahantaṃ sammāsambuddhaṃ piṭṭhito piṭṭhito anubandhi.
segments.en: Then Vidhura, with blood pouring from his cracked skull, still followed behind the Buddha Kakusandha.

segments.pli: Atha kho, pāpima, kakusandho bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho nāgāpalokitaṃ apalokesi:
segments.en: Then the Buddha Kakusandha turned his whole body, the way that elephants do, to look back, saying,
‘This Māra Dūsī knows no bounds.’

segments.pli: Sahāpalokanāya ca pana, pāpima, dūsī māro tamhā ca ṭhānā cavi mahānirayañca upapajji.
segments.en: And with that look Māra Dūsī fell from that place and was reborn in the Great Hell.

segments.pli: Tassa kho pana, pāpima, mahānirayassa tayo nāmadheyyā honti—
segments.en: Now that Great Hell is known by three names:

segments.pli: chaphassāyataniko itipi, saṅkusamāhato itipi, paccattavedaniyo itipi.
segments.en: ‘The Six Fields of Contact’ and also ‘The Impaling With Spikes’ and also ‘Individually Painful’.

segments.pli: Atha kho maṃ, pāpima, nirayapālā upasaṅkamitvā etadavocuṃ:
segments.en: Then the wardens of hell came to me and said,

segments.pli: ‘yadā kho te, mārisa, saṅkunā saṅku hadaye samāgaccheyya.
segments.en: ‘When stake meets stake in your heart,
you will know that
you’ve been roasting in hell for a thousand years.’

segments.pli: So kho ahaṃ, pāpima, bahūni vassāni bahūni vassasatāni bahūni vassasahassāni tasmiṃ mahāniraye apacciṃ.
segments.en: I roasted for many years, many centuries, many millennia in that Great Hell.

segments.pli: Dasavassasahassāni tasseva mahānirayassa ussade apacciṃ vuṭṭhānimaṃ nāma vedanaṃ vediyamāno.
segments.en: For ten thousand years I roasted in the annex of that Great Hell, experiencing the pain called ‘coming out’.

segments.pli: Tassa mayhaṃ, pāpima, evarūpo kāyo hoti, seyyathāpi manussassa.
segments.en: My body was in human form,
but I had the head of a fish.
What kind of hell was that,
where Dūsī was roasted
after attacking the disciple Vidhura
along with the brahmin Kakusandha?
There were 100 iron spikes,
each one individually painful.
That’s the kind of hell
where Dūsī was roasted
after attacking the disciple Vidhura
along with the brahmin Kakusandha.
Dark One, if you attack
a mendicant who directly knows this,
a disciple of the Buddha,
you’ll fall into suffering.
There are mansions that last for an eon
standing in the middle of a lake.
Sapphire-colored, brilliant,
they sparkle and shine.
Dancing there are nymphs
shining in all different colors.
Dark One, if you attack
a mendicant who directly knows this,
a disciple of the Buddha,
you’ll fall into suffering.
I’m the one who, encouraged by the Buddha,
shook the stilt longhouse of Migāra’s mother
with his big toe
as the Saṅgha of mendicants watched.
Dark One, if you attack
a mendicant who directly knows this,
a disciple of the Buddha,
you’ll fall into suffering.
I’m the one who shook the Palace of Victory
with his big toe
owing to psychic power,
inspiring deities to awe.
Dark One, if you attack
a mendicant who directly knows this,
a disciple of the Buddha,
you’ll fall into suffering.
I’m the one who asked Sakka
in the Palace of Victory:
‘Vāsava, do you know the freedom
that comes with the ending of craving?’
And I’m the one to whom Sakka
admitted the truth when asked.
Dark One, if you attack
a mendicant who directly knows this,
a disciple of the Buddha,
you’ll fall into suffering.
I’m the one who asked Brahmā
in the Hall of Justice before the assembly:
‘Friend, do you still have the same view
that you had in the past?
Or do you see the radiance
transcending the Brahmā realm?’
And I’m the one to whom Brahmā
truthfully admitted his progress:
‘Good sir, I don’t have that view
that I had in the past.
I see the radiance
transcending the Brahmā realm.
So how could I say today
that I am permanent and eternal?’
Dark One, if you attack
a mendicant who directly knows this,
a disciple of the Buddha,
you’ll fall into suffering.
I’m the one who has touched the peak of Mount Meru
using the power of meditative liberation.
I’ve visited the forests of the people
who dwell in the Eastern Continent.
Dark One, if you attack
a mendicant who directly knows this,
a disciple of the Buddha,
you’ll fall into suffering.
Though a fire doesn’t think,
‘I’ll burn the fool!’
Still the fool who attacks
the fire gets burnt.
In the same way, Māra,
in attacking the Realized One,
you’ll only burn yourself,
like a fool touching the flames.
Māra’s done a bad thing
in attacking the Realized One.
Wicked One, do you imagine that
your wickedness won’t bear fruit?
Your deeds heap up wickedness
that will last a long time, terminator!
Forget about the Buddha, Māra!
And give up your hopes for the mendicants!”
That is how, in the Bhesekaḷā grove,
the mendicant rebuked Māra.
That spirit, downcast,
disappeared right there!

segments.pli: Dūsī ca māro dasamo ca vaggo.

suttaplex.blurb: Māra, the trickster and god of death, tried to annoy Moggallāna. He not only failed but was subject to a stern sermon warning of the dangers of attacking the Buddha’s disciples.

translations.author: I.B. Horner
translations.title: Discourse On A Rebuke To Māra
